/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: LGTM

Mostly looks good to me. I think if lookup() is handling the Command.result RowView case, it should handle the RowView case outside of the command as well--not sure if we should do it in a separate patch or just handle it here.

As completely unrelated aside, one of these days we may need to fix RowView. In cases where there is a referenced Row as a column, it returns that Row object and should probably return a RowView--I've held off because I didn't want to pay the price of recursively converting fields. But we can probably just make the conversion happen on-demand.
LGTM. I didn't remember/realize at the time I suggested it that os-vif still had the vsctl backend. If we need to backport this I guess we can just leave out the api change.
os-vif patch: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-vif/+/872391

ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/__init__.py.message: Should we also outside of Command objects have lookup(RowView()) return the RowView?

Sorry, I don't get what you are trying to explain here. Does it mean that in case of type(result)=RowView, we should do a lookup(RowView)?

If so, why should we need it? Because the register could have been updated?

ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands..message:
lookup() should already handle this case https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/5f429b72303abbad7bbd88dfc621166e3faabf90/ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/__init__.py#L192

Do you think it'd make sense to also just add support for Rows/RowViews as being equivalent to uuid in lookup()?

OK, I got it, maybe you can then fix it here:
https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/149d7db4a70fd9c87a6b6fe8275d779babd30374/ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py#L1752
and here:
https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/149d7db4a70fd9c87a6b6fe8275d779babd30374/ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py#L1462
so that everywhere there is the same behavior?
I'll create a launchpad bug to deal with these divergent method and push a patch to fix them.

> By default, if we create a new register, we return the UUID only

@Rodolfo, can you please explain in more detail. I checked with my patch and without it, adding a new entity or adding an existing one with 'may_exist' option returns the RowView. This logic is in the AddCommand.post_commit(). What am I doing wrong?
But then post_commit() makes sure that the result contains a RowView https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/149d7db4a70fd9c87a6b6fe8275d779babd30374/ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/command.py#L81

I also solved this problem for LoadBalancers, NATs and Routes, but I have not had time to send a request yet. To make it work I changed the assignment of the result here: https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/5f429b72303abbad7bbd88dfc621166e3faabf90/ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py#L1776

I wrote like this:
self.result = hcg

If the *Command class is inherited from AddCommand class, and the entire result of the transaction is stored in a "result", and this *Command can be passed as an argument to any other commands. At the same time, in the add command, you need to specify all the columns that will be modified by subsequent commands, otherwise you will have to write a 'getattr()' for all columns in all commands.
But maybe i'm wrong.
Right, if can handle UUID, BaseCommand and RowViews in the _lookup method, that will simplify any other command. I'll test that.

Check any "add" command. The result returned is the UUID of the new register. For example: https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/149d7db4a70fd9c87a6b6fe8275d779babd30374/ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py#L1776

But this is after the "run_idl" execution. During a transaction, the add command will return in "result" the UUID of the new register. This is what we'll read in the next command that accepts the add command as input.

If we read the add command output when the transaction is finished, we receive the RewView object. But in this case, we need to differentiate if the add command returns an UUID (the register is being added within this transaction) or returns a RowView (the register already exists during this transaction).

This is why I did this: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ovsdbapp/+/871836/8/ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/__init__.py#195

@Anton, I don't think we should change what an add command returns right now. By default, if we create a new register, we return the UUID only. If the register is already created, we return the RowView.

What we need to adapt is the lookup method.

It seems that all these cases are already processed in the AddCommand.post_commit(), and in order to be able to pass the HAChassisGroupAdd command to another command, you need to change the assignment of the result as I wrote above.

One thing that concerns me is that ovsdbapp is a general purpose library and changing name of an argument can break users who use keyword arguments. Perhaps we should get hcg_id from **columns and print a deprecation message?

api.Command should probably also specify a "result" abstract property if it is something that other Backends should be required to support. (Just in case some day we get to resurrect the vsctl backend into an ovn-sbctl daemon mode backend, etc.)

Done

Actually checking some implementations for api.Command, I found [1] (incorrectly implemented, because this class should be abstract).

In order to implement this abstract property, I would need first to change the os-vif code.

playbooks/roles/gerrit/tasks/start.yaml.message:
It is probably over-engineering this ... but I wonder if this could be a variable that stamps when it was done.  For example, you'd have something like

 # these versions require a reindex before starting when upgrading
 gerrit_upgrade_reindex:
   - 3.6
   - 3.X
  
and a task that first checks the gerrit version, and if it's in the upgrade_reindex list, then looks for '/var/gerrit/stamp/{{ version }}.reindex.stamp', and if it's not there, runs the reindex and makes the stamp ...

Seems like we could actually use that in the upgrade checklist too...

I think this would be a good thing to implement if we wanted to fully automate the Gerrit installs. However, I think that is well beyond having a simple test for the upgrade?

I worry that this will complicate something that is simple today with little benefit beyond the test if we don't get to the point of automated upgrades.

That said I think automated upgrades would be neat to implement, but maybe we can have this sort of tooling when we get there?

Would 
 columns["label"] = random.randrange(1, 2**32)
 
be the same and avoid the while loop?
In case it would, the "2**32" part should be a module level constant calculated just once on module import :)
Done! I used 2**32 - 1 as MAX_INT_LABEL since the interval starts at 0

I think it should be just 2**32 as the stop value is excluded from the range:

https://docs.python.org/3/library/random.html#random.randrange
https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#range

"For a positive step, the contents of a range r are determined by the formula r[i] = start + step*i where i >= 0 and r[i] < stop."

Thanks for the review melwitt. I have addressed your two comments re: related options in `conf/workarounds.py`

Whilst I cannot accurately gauge the usage of this workaround in the community, it does appear to be in use in not just my organization based on the fact that someone else committed the option of announce_self originally.

I agree that the code-base shouldn't be bloated for the sake of it and workarounds given unnecessary sub-options and so on. As 99% of people probably don't even configure a workarounds section for Nova, this ought to be low impact to those users. For the users who have issues with certain live migration scenarios, this may be extremely useful.

There are a number of considerations when using announce_self, as fabrics may have an imposed arp packet limit over a period of time for example. Depending on the number of migrations that take place, it may not be suitable to send numerous attempts in quick succession.

Or, in our case, we have to send 3 attempts to ensure a VM that has been live migrated is accessible on the network (I performed nearly 20,000 live migration tests in different scenarios to test this theory)


The hardcoded options simply didn't yield the desired effect for us, and I'd wager that this is the case for other fabrics in the wild too - having a on/off toggle for this workaround isn't appropriate as the effectiveness depends on the particular use-case and thus fine-tuning is going to be required in a lot of cases.


Any further comment welcomed, thank you

I feel convinced of the necessity of the workaround sub-options and why a hard-coding of reasonable values for the retry is unlikely to work well enough for all, given the wide variety of potential network fabrics. So, this looks OK to me.

Thanks for the approval melwitt and sean.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/124692/what-is-the-intended-use-of-the-default-section-in-config-files-used-by-configpa

Maybe it's to make it look different since its settings will propagate to all other sections or maybe it's just tradition. I found some inconsistent capitalizations throughout our config doc but the hyperlinking works either way, which is the most important thing.

our upgrade requirement do not allow the type of a config option to be changed form into to bool so if we were to do that it would requrie the config option to be deprecated and a new one to be added. however as is said in my previoius revew the simplest solution is to keep the orginal enable config option unchange as a bool to opt into the behavior and just add the addtaional paramters.

we likely will eventually remove the workaround options and the self announch code at some point in the future. the code should really not be requried and its a workaorund for neutron backend that do not conform with the contract between nova and neutorn.

the contract between nova and neutron is that network-vif—plugged is only sent when the backend is fully configured. ovn and several other backend does not conform to that and this workaround option was added to workaround the bug in the neutron backend impelmation.

If you try and specify 'True' for an `IntOpt` then the service will error because oslo_config fails to verify the configuration, similar to if you specify a value other than `0` or `1` for a BoolOpt.


So I believe this leaves two options:

1) Revert to patch-set 8, where a new option specifying the number of retries is added, which retains backwards compatibility

or...

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> There is a straightforward way of allowing cli authentication by using the tokens issued by a zuul admin, and you have the parent change to support direct access grants.

Direct access grants are not recommended in production, as explained in the OAuth2.0 RFC:

   This grant type carries a higher risk than other grant types because
   it maintains the password anti-pattern this protocol seeks to avoid.
   The client could abuse the password, or the password could
   unintentionally be disclosed to an attacker (e.g., via log files or
   other records kept by the client). [...]

   The authorization server and client SHOULD minimize use of this grant
   type and utilize other grant types whenever possible.

See https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-10.7

> I'm not sure I've seen this JWT-to-localhost paradigm used before, and it seems complex, fragile and relies on a lot of things going right (localhost being added to the provider, being able to run in a location with a web server, etc).  Is it really worth the effort?

It is indeed troublesome, but this seems to be the accepted way to support OpenIDConnect with a CLI: 

https://medium.com/keycloak/using-keycloak-x-with-cli-applications-38bbff9f9c96
https://devconfcz2022.sched.com/event/siIY/securing-command-line-applications-with-keycloak

> We've put a lot of effort into bringing the web ui up to par with the client; why not accept it as the first-class method of interacting with zuul, and for sites that can't use either of the above methods, accept that the users are best served by using the web ui?

True, given that if you can use the web auth workflow, you should also be able to use the GUI.

Does this mean we will be dropping support for single non-parsed entries like "job", "view", etc.... if we merge the feature later in this change chain?

If so, I guess I'm not against that since I think job-template is much more useful than "job" and can be used statically if you really want but with extra steps. (Apologies if this is obvious further down the change chain since I don't have time to go through and fully understand everything in this chain of changes just yet but am trying to slowly look at them.)

author.name: Thanh Ha
author.status: On Leave

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Thanks for explaining. That sounds reasonable. I don't have much time so don't expect quick reviews but I'm trying to get through my review queue one at a time when I have a moment to spare. 😊

No. Change in review up the chain does not remove standalone job and view support. It only changes parser logic which affects duplicate checks. In that change, jobs listed in a projects are just ignored. Because that's actually is no-op in current implementation - listing jobs in a project does not affect jobs instantiation.

But I have plans to remove standalone jobs and views in favor of templates. Also I have plans to always expand macros, have they parameters passed to them or not. But these will go in separate reviews, after I create tasks with detailed explanation why that should be done. And after I raise this issue in mail list, with same explanation. And only after that I want to assign new major version.

By the way, I am glad you are back! It really helps knowing someone with better knowledge reviews my changes.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: do we know how it can happen like that? Shouldn't this key be set always?

Yes and despite this, I have this situation in my env right now. I don't know exactly how I ended having this LSP without external_ids information. But this is the only place in ovn_client where we don't check what is retrieved from this dict

Do you happen to know how this could be ? We always add this information to the LSP external_ids [0] for every port we create. Are these ports created by some other system that is not ML2/OVN ?

[0] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/b71b25820be6d61ed9f249eddf32bfa49ac76524/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/ovn_client.py#L546-L547

Let's see what other reviewers think.

I would rather let things fail if the database is manually modified because it would be impossible to address every case if that happens to all resources. I don't see why we would make this one a exception to the rule.

I see but, we do have an assumption in ML2/OVN that the driver "owns" these databases, in that case this error would never happen.

My fear is setting a precedent here because others resources would also start failing if we remove external_ids flags from them, why would we make Logical Switch Port an exception ?

Yes, that happened to me when manually modifying the NB database. I'm not saying this is something expected or recommended, for sure, but the "check_for_inconsistencies" method should not fail due to this error. Actually it should be resilient to this possibility.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Hello folks, can you review this patch? Thanks in advance.
Questions inline

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: nit: this can be moved to L800 (before else clause) and You will have just one "if ovn_network_name" condition.
why this new condition is added here too? Should You then update comment in L813?
well, this is mandatory to avoid "ls_get" returning an exception if the network name is empty or None. In any case, I'll update it.

So in the case the network ID is not in in the LSP external_ids we will not be calling the "self._qos_driver.delete_port()" method. What's the implication here ? 

Is it safe to assume that a port without that external_id field is not present in QoS ? Are we at risk of leaving some left over in the DB ?

As you commented, we always set the network name in the LSP. If we have manually modified the LSP, then this is our responsibility to delete the leftovers.

In the case I reported [1], the LSP was manually added in the database. The "check_for_inconsistencies" called the OVNClient.delete_port method to remove this orphan register but failed here. With this patch we are ensuring that the LSP is deleted and the "check_for_inconsistencies" doesn't fail and stop the DB cleanup. If there is a related QoS register, we can't remove it without the network info.

[1]https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/2000252

actions/ceph_ops.py.message: It would probably be more elegant to have a new custom exception type that this function raises in the event of any of its failures, and then that can be caught by callers to handle the exceptional case. Returning a str on error is a really unfortunate design choice from C.
All `action_fail` does is to call a Juju binary to fail the action; it doesn't do anything like an early-return.
This and the other call to `action_fail` are going to be overridden by the one in `get_versions_report`. It's not necessarily a mistake, but it's a pointless call.

actions/get_versions_report.py.message:
`get_versions_report` doesn't raise a CalledProcessError, so this block isn't currently called. If the `action_fail`s in that function were updated to raise an exception rather than call `action_fail`, those could be caught here, which would make this catch useful.

In addition, it would allow actually bailing when an exception happens in that function rather than continuing on through things that will likely all continue failing after the first one.

Hello Wu, Thank you for your reply:)

Hi Wu! Chould you please check this PR?

Temporary files exist in the `/tmp` directory where only file owner can update them.　Here are easy steps to check this file permission problem:

#1. Let's login to a Guest VM, and creates a temporary file that `ubuntu(uid is 1000)` owns.
```
echo "SELECT 1;" > /tmp/test.sql
chmod 777 /tmp/test.sql
```

#2. Let's fork a mysql docker container process by `database(uidis 1001` user, mounting `/tmp` directory from Docker host.
```
docker run --rm --name database_test --network bridge --mount 'type=bind,src=/tmp,dst=/tmp' --user '1001:1001' -ti 10.0.0.22:5000/testuser/mysql:5.7.40 /bin/bash
```

#3. Let's try updating the temporary file, then you will get `Permission denied`.
```
bash-4.2$ echo test | tee -a /tmp/test.sql
tee: /tmp/test.sql: Permission denied
test
bash-4.2$ ls -l /tmp/test.sql
-rwxrwxrwx 1 1000 1000 56 Jan 26 16:33 /tmp/test.sql
```
I would like to write a tempest test case for this scenario, but I am really not familiar with tempest.😊😊😊

Yes, it needs to be run as root because the keyring is under /etc/ceph instead of /var/lib/ceph/ .  I'll add a comment to clarify.

lib/charms_ceph/utils.py.message: Is this change related to adding the crash keyring?

Kind of - it's a bug in that part of the code that is exposed when there's a file in that directory that doesn't contain a dash (eg. the new client.crash.keyring).  Previously the bug was hidden because all files inadvertently had dashes.  See https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charms.ceph/+/869272 where I've also submitted the patch upstream.

templates/ceph.conf.message: What happens here when we have a configured keyring but no file there?

No such file or directory warning will be recorded when trying to post a crash file but OSD itself works. It's actually configured already with the default path, but we didn't have a keyring there so far.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
OK, it took me a while to page this all back in ...

This is all very different in the gate, because we use the buildset-registry, which is essentially a staging server.  It makes this all quite mind-bending!

Basically when the images are built, they are tagged with {{ zj_image.repository }}/image:change_12345_latest by the container build process.

Then upload-container-image pushes this tag to the {{ zj_image.repository }}

Then the existing promote path gets the manifest of {{ zj_image.repository }}/image:change_12345_latest and puts it back as {{ zj_image.repository }}/image:latest to finalise everything.

In this proposed case, as I understand it, the build stays the same, and it's still going to be tagged by the build process with {{ zj_image.repository }}/image:change_12345_latest by the build process

But then, when we promote here, instead of pushing this tag to {{ zj_image.repository }}, we are going to look at {{ stage_registry.repository }} and re-tag the image as {{ stage_registry.repository }}/image:change_12345 with

  - name: Rename image
    command: "{{ container_command }} tag {{ zj_image.repository }}:{{ zj_push_tag }} {{ zj_repository }}:{{ zj_push_tag }}"
    when: zj_repository != zj_image.repository
    
when the repository setup in zj_image.repository is *not* the same as the staging registry (which is set in zj_repository).  And then we push to the staging server (zj_repository).

Now I see that this is supposed to be combined with the follow-on change for Artifactory; which as I understand it -- instead of the promote renaming the image, it calls a /promote API end-point with a bit of json to essentially ask Artifactory to move the image from the stage repository to the "live" repository?

So ... with all that as my context ...

Could you just set the existing zj_image.repository to the Artifactory staging repository for the build and upload steps, and basically not modify anything to get the initial image upload?  

Then, in the artifactory promote role, pass via arguments the credentials/paths/etc. so that you can make the API call to move it from the staging server to the final place?

Basically I don't understand why we need to keep all the information about the final publishing location through the build+upload steps here.  It seems like something that can be isolated to arguments for the final promote?

The advantage of this, I think, is that we don't need to modify the extant build-container-image/upload-container-image path with this idea of a staging server.  It already has branches all-over for the buildset-registry, and this introduces another concept to it...

> OK, it took me a while to page this all back in ...
> 
> This is all very different in the gate, because we use the buildset-registry, which is essentially a staging server.  It makes this all quite mind-bending!
> 
> Basically when the images are built, they are tagged with {{ zj_image.repository }}/image:change_12345_latest by the container build process.

>     when: zj_repository != zj_image.repository

> when the repository setup in zj_image.repository is *not* the same as the staging registry (which is set in zj_repository).  And then we push to the staging server (zj_repository).
> 
> Now I see that this is supposed to be combined with the follow-on change for Artifactory; which as I understand it -- instead of the promote renaming the image, it calls a /promote API end-point with a bit of json to essentially ask Artifactory to move the image from the stage repository to the "live" repository?

Correct

> 
> So ... with all that as my context ...
> 
> Could you just set the existing zj_image.repository to the Artifactory staging repository for the build and upload steps, and basically not modify anything to get the initial image upload?  
> 
> Then, in the artifactory promote role, pass via arguments the credentials/paths/etc. so that you can make the API call to move it from the staging server to the final place?
> 
> Basically I don't understand why we need to keep all the information about the final publishing location through the build+upload steps here.  It seems like something that can be isolated to arguments for the final promote?

Ah, I could see why, and I think there is a missing piece of context. What I want to do is setup our projects so that they can "manage" their own Docker images for their jobs inside their own project; basically, they make a Dockerfile in the project, and there are pre-canned zuul jobs that will efficiently build the image, upload in gate, promote after merge, etc. Importantly, it does all of these things efficiently, so that it only actually rebuilds the image when it changes (since it could take a long time), otherwise it pulls the image from the published artifactory repo before starting the job to skip the long build step.

The problem is that pull from artifactory for the actual build jobs. I'd _really_ like to use https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul-jobs/+/871849 because this makes it super easy and seamless; just add this role to your pre-run, and set the exact same `container_images` variables in your job as all the other container build jobs and it will automatically and correctly either pull from the local buildset registry, or the published artifactory. I think `pull-container-images` is useful for other testing use cases, but it's really useful if it can just reuse the `container_images` variable; I could of course make a separate set of variables for `pull-container-images`, but I also think it's (generally) unexpected from a users perspective that container_images.repository doesn't point to the published images like it would in every other case.

> 
> The advantage of this, I think, is that we don't need to modify the extant build-container-image/upload-container-image path with this idea of a staging server.  It already has branches all-over for the buildset-registry, and this introduces another concept to it...

Note the Zuul -1 is due to a depricated tox config which will be fixed when [1] is merged.

manila/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
is there any difference between doing this, vs:

   message_ref.save(context.session) 
   
   
Since we're creating a single record, could we just use .save here for consistency?

Thanks Stephen, agree with your take to not modify the behavior here - afaiu, we don't need to flush here since there's no need for sqlalchemy to give us any autogenerated data for the messages model. I'm okay leaving the .save implementation elsewhere - i see the usage in nova/cinder etc as well;

'Model.save' isn't actually defined in SQLAlchemy - it's an oslo.db addition [1]. We could use it here but it's not an identical operation (it also results in a flush). I'd rather not do any more functional changes that needed while migrating things over, but it'd be a good follow-up perhaps if you'd like?

Alternatively, I can replace all calls to 'Model.save' with 'session.add' and 'session.flush' calls, so things look more like "upstream" SQLAlchemy. Whatever works for you guys...

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/32b042e7069f90c61548d73e3460ab8e0f6990c7/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/models.py#L35-L38

doc/source/user/index.rst.message:
It seems more complicated than this, because of the new config values (default_master_volume_type etc). I think the precedence is now:

master_volume_X, default_master_volume_X, boot_volume_X, default_boot_volume_X

Is that how you want it to work?
I removed default master and minion volume sizes - in case they're missing they fall back straight to boot volume size. Updating docs accordingly.
Ok. That precedence at least needs to be documented, since the docs don't mention the new default_master_volume_X config options.
Yes that was the idea from the beginning - to use (master|minion)_volume_ vars if we want to override specific type of node, fallback to boot_volume if absent.

magnum/drivers/heat/k8s_fedora_template_.message: This will always be defined, because it falls back to a random type.
Fixed that, now master and minion volume types no longer use "random" configuration if missing - they just take the value from boot_volume_type instead.

ok, concrete example.

master_volume_type unset
default_master_volume_type unset
boot_volume_type = foo
boot_volume_size = 1

In this case, we would pass in master_volume_type as a random volume type. In the template, that random volume type would override the requested boot_volume_type of foo.

The fix is to never return a random type from get_default_master_volume_type.

Do you mean master_volume_type? It will fall back to random type by cluster.labels.get() if master_volume_type missing from labels, unless (master|boot)_volume_size in line 247 equals 0 (default when not defined) then it sets master_volume_type to empty string in 252. 

This again, is used inside heat templates, in conditions - copying logical solution from original boot_volume_type label.

So basically if volume size is set (which is evaluated in heat template conditional to recognize if instance will be image or volume based) then we care about master volume type. Disregard otherwise.

This follows the original behaviour of boot_volume_type. Or am I missing something?
I think this condition will be covered by L249 and L255, so could be removed.

With boot_volume_size not set, master_volume_size and boot_volume_type present in the labels, this would cause boot_volume_type to be set wrong to '' in L245. With master_volume_type not set it would be expected to fallback to boot_volume_type in L250. We need to set boot_volume_type if master/worker_volume_size is used, even if boot_volume_size is not used - to allow for using boot_volume_type+master_volume_size+minion_volume_size combo.

This will never get used. If boot_volume_size is set, master_volume_size will default to it. That means on L249 we will specify master_volume_type.

Better to just remove the original boot_* parameters from the template?

(same with L227)
Since, in the templates we no longer use boot_volume_type maybe we can drop this completely? (and pass only master/worker_volume_type)
There's no default value for these parameters in the template. Won't that be a problem if we are conditionally passing them in?
I don't think so - in L230 we set it to boot_volume_size if master_volume_size is not present. So master/worker_volume_size will always be set to 'some' value.
I think we do not need this check if you are not doing `cinder.get_default_boot_volume()` or similar calls. Setting a type do not any harm if size=0?

Indeed, it looks like this conditional could be dropped. In kubemaster/mimion yaml we use _volume_size in conditional so setting (master|worker)_volume_type should not interfere.

I would like to test if it wouldn't fail in case of image based nodes.

I'm only suggesting to remove the parameters in the cluster template. They would still be handled as labels by the Python code. But the template only needs to know the final value of size & type for the master & minions.

If it helps, try to consider these parameters as separate from the labels.
These are unused in this template and should be removed.

ansible/roles/rabbitmq/templates/definit.message:
One other thing to note, is that this patch moves in the direction of making transient queues non-mirrored, which is a good thing [1]:

```
Semantically using transient entities (as in AMQP 0-9-1) and asking the system to replicate them makes no sense. The above example only confirms this: if you pin a transient queue to two nodes and they are both down, what should happen? Should this queue exist or not when the nodes come back up and promotion of out-of-sync mirrors is allowed? It is transient and all of its designated nodes were offline at some point; but it is also mirrored and promotion is allowed. I don't have an answer, as this combination of settings is too unlikely to be set intentionally.
```
[1] https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-server/issues/2045

Perhaps a good place to start, is to consider which queues should be mirrored (and durable), if any, and then expand the regex in this patch to cover all transient queues.

Looking at a Victoria deployment with a 3 node control plane, I don't see any durable exchanges or queues at all, except for the internal `amq.*` exchanges:

```
(rabbitmq)[rabbitmq@stack1 /]$ rabbitmqctl list_exchanges durable, name, type   | grep true
true	amq.topic	topic
true	amq.rabbitmq.trace	topic
true	amq.headers	headers
true	amq.direct	direct
true		direct
true	amq.fanout	fanout
true	amq.match	headers
```

```
(rabbitmq)[rabbitmq@intern-control3 /]$ rabbitmqctl list_queues type,durable, name | grep true | wc -l
0
```

So, I am confused about whether we should change these internal `amq.*` exchanges.

The discussion from OSA implies there was a reason:

```
16:04:44 <gsantomaggio> I am looking how Open Stack does use RabbitMQ,
16:04:44 <gsantomaggio> I found this HA policy:
16:04:44 <gsantomaggio> https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/openstack-ansible-rabbitmq_server/tree/defaults/main.yml#n154
16:04:44 <gsantomaggio> If I am not wrong, open stack does not use the autodelete queues anymore.
16:04:44 <gsantomaggio> It works using queues with TTL, right?
16:04:45 <gsantomaggio> So, this policy should be changed from '^(?!amq\.).*'  to '^(?!reply_\.).*'
16:04:45 <gsantomaggio> What do you think?
```

But when I look, I see plenty of queues with autodelete, but not the `amq.*` ones:

```
(rabbitmq)[rabbitmq@intern-control3 /]$ rabbitmqctl list_exchanges auto_delete, name, type | grep false
false   amq.direct      direct
false   amq.topic       topic
false   amq.rabbitmq.trace      topic
false   amq.match       headers
false   amq.headers     headers
false           direct
false   neutron topic
false   nova    topic
false   heat    topic
false   amq.fanout      fanout
false   openstack       topic
```

```
(rabbitmq)[rabbitmq@intern-control3 /]$ rabbitmqctl list_exchanges auto_delete, name, type | grep true
true    engine_worker_fanout    fanout
true    q-agent-notifier-dvr-update_fanout      fanout
true    q-agent-notifier-network-update_fanout  fanout
true    q-agent-notifier-security_group-update_fanout   fanout
true    q-agent-notifier-network-delete_fanout  fanout
true    neutron-vo-Port-1.5_fanout      fanout
true    neutron-vo-SubPort-1.0_fanout   fanout
true    q-agent-notifier-port-delete_fanout     fanout
true    q-reports-plugin_fanout fanout
true    q-agent-notifier-l2population-update_fanout     fanout
true    q-agent-notifier-tunnel-update_fanout   fanout
true    cinder-volume.intern-control1.dl@rbd-1_fanout   fanout
true    neutron-vo-SecurityGroupRule-1.0_fanout fanout
true    cinder-scheduler_fanout fanout
true    dhcp_agent_fanout       fanout
true    neutron-vo-Subnet-1.1_fanout    fanout
true    q-agent-notifier-port-update_fanout     fanout
true    compute_fanout  fanout
true    heat-engine-listener_fanout     fanout
true    scheduler_fanout        fanout
true    q-l3-plugin_fanout      fanout
true    cinder-volume.intern-control3.dl@rbd-1_fanout   fanout
true    q-server-resource-versions_fanout       fanout
true    q-agent-notifier-tunnel-delete_fanout   fanout
true    cinder-backup_fanout    fanout
true    engine_fanout   fanout
true    cinder-volume.intern-control2.dl@rbd-1_fanout   fanout
true    l3_agent_fanout fanout
true    neutron-vo-Trunk-1.1_fanout     fanout
true    neutron-vo-SecurityGroup-1.2_fanout     fanout
true    cinder-volume_fanout    fanout
true    neutron-vo-Network-1.1_fanout   fanout
true    conductor_fanout        fanout
true    q-plugin_fanout fanout
```

`amq.*` queues not being listed as auto-delete, doesn't match with the OSA release note:

```
---
upgrade:
  - |
    The default queue policy has changed to ``^(?!(amq\.)|(.*_fanout_)|(reply_)).*``
    instead of ``^(?!amq\.).*`` for efficiency.
    The new HA policy excludes reply queues (these queues have a single consumer and TTL policy),
    fanout queues (they have the TTL policy) and
    amq queues (they are auto-delete queues, with a single consumer).
```

Aside: I assume the TTL policy in the above release note comes in via rpc_timeout or something in the service configuration as I don't see any TTL polices, or operator policies in the Rabbit CLI.

The other thing to consider (perhaps not here), is that where we have HA queues, they will eventually need to become quorum queues [1]:

```
Removal of Classic Queue mirroring

Why are we making this decision?
Quorum Queues provide greater data safety as compared to classic mirrored queues.

```

[1] https://blog.rabbitmq.com/posts/2021/08/4.0-deprecation-announcements/

TLDR is that more investigation is required.

- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/863446 Proxy: add metrics related to error limiter

Please fix.

What does this & do?
It seems like you are backgrounding the process

OK, so this backgrounds it
ntpq -pnc rv &1

but this does not
ntpq -pnc "rv &1"

so since the subprocess passes in "rv &<num>"  as a single arg, the syntax is fine.

In this case it is a command that is passed as a value to the "-c" parameter (see the variable above). NTPQ has several internal commands to perform certain tasks. In this case, the "rv &x" command is being passed, where x represents the association ID returned by the output of the ntpq command, and with it, get the IPv6 address as described in the commit description.

cinder/volume/drivers/hitachi/hbsd_commo.message: should've been hitachi_pools but then again it needs to go through the deprecation cycle and a new config needs to be added so I'm fine with this
I see. Thank you for letting me know your concern.

You could change the name to 'hitachi_pools' and add

  deprecated_name='hitachi_pool',

to the definition and oslo.config will look for either one in the config file.

I think the more important issue is that you ordinarily don't want to change the type of the option because that could break existing config files.  Luckily the default for bounds in a ListOpt is False, so oslo.config won't require the list to be enclosed in a pair of square brackets.  Thus an existing pool name will automatically converted by oslo.config into a list containing a single item, so this change shouldn't break any existing config files.
